Okot p'Bitek was a prominent Ugandan poet, novelist, and anthropologist. His notable works include:  African Dilemma 1973 Song of Lawino 1966 Song of Ocol 1970 Religion of the Sorcerers 1971 The Horns of Darkness 1973 The Challenge of Africa 1975

Ngugi wa Thiong'o is a prominent Kenyan author known for his contributions to East African literature. Some of his notable works include:  Weep Not, Child (1964) - a novel set during the Mau Mau uprising in Kenya The River Between (1965) - a novel exploring themes of cultural identity and colonialism A Grain of Wheat (1967) - a novel that critiques colonialism and its legacy in Kenya Secret Lives (1975) - a novel that explores themes of identity, power, and social change Caitani Mutharaba-ini (1977) - a novel that tells the story of a young boy's journey to manhood Devil on the Cross (1982) - a novel that critiques capitalist exploitation and the effects of colonialism Matigari ma Njiru Ngithi (1986) - a novel that explores themes of identity, power, and social change The River Between and Other Stories (1991) - a collection of short stories Wizard of the Crow (2006) - a novel that critiques the politics of post-colonial Africa In the House of the Interpreter (2009) - a novel that explores themes of identity, power, and social change Finding Vetiver (2016) - a memoir that explores the author's life and experiences.  Ngugi wa Thiong'o's works often explore themes of cultural identity, colonialism, and social change, and are known for their nuanced portrayals of East African experiences.

Meja Mwangi is a Kenyan novelist known for his works that often depict the harsh realities of urban life in Nairobi. Two notable books by Meja Mwangi that focus on Nairobi's street children are:  Dust of Life (1975)  Going Down River Road (1976)

Ngugi wa Thiong'o is a prominent Kenyan author, best known for his contributions to East African literature and his advocacy for decolonization through language and culture. Some of his notable works include:  Decolonizing the Mind (1986)  - This non-fiction work critiques the effects of colonialism on African literature and culture, arguing for the importance of reclaiming indigenous languages and cultural heritage.  Weep Not, Child (1964)  - A semi-autobiographical novel that explores the Mau Mau Uprising and its impact on the lives of ordinary Kenyans during the colonial period.  The River Between (1965)  - A novel that examines the tensions between traditional and modern ways of life in a rural Kenyan community.  Matigari ma Njiru Ngithii (1989)  - A novel that tells the story of a man who returns to his village after a long absence, only to find that the community has been transformed by colonialism and modernization.  Devil on the Cross (1982)  - A novel written in Gikuyu, the author's native language, that explores the experiences of a group of travelers who are forced to confront the harsh realities of post-colonial Kenya.  The Black Hermit (1978)  - A novel that examines the complexities of identity, culture, and politics in a small Kenyan town.  In the House of the Interpreter (1978)  - A novel that explores the relationships between language, culture, and power in a small Kenyan town.  Caitani Mutharaba-ini (1980)  - A novel written in Gikuyu, which explores the complexities of identity, culture, and politics in a small Kenyan town.  The River Between and Weep Not, Child are notable for their exploration of the tensions between traditional and modern ways of life in rural Kenya, while Devil on the Cross and Matigari ma Njiru Ngithii showcase the author's use of Gikuyu language and his commitment to decolonizing the mind.  Ngugi wa Thiong'o's work is characterized by its focus on the experiences of ordinary people, its exploration of the complexities of identity, culture, and politics, and its commitment to decolonizing the mind and reclaiming indigenous languages and cultural heritage.

Ngugi wa Thiong'o is a renowned Kenyan author, known for his contributions to East African literature. His notable works include:  Decolonising the Mind: The Politics of Language in African Literature (1986)  The River Between (1965) Weep Not, Child (1964) A Grain of Wheat (1967) Matigari (1986) Devil on the Cross (1982) The Black Hermit (1978) Caitani Mutharaba-ini (1969) Ngaahika Ndeke (1977) I Will Marry When I Want (1982) The Trial of Dedan Kimathi (1975)  Ngugi wa Thiong'o is known for his exploration of themes such as decolonization, identity, and the role of language in shaping culture. His works often draw on his experiences growing up in colonial Kenya and his involvement in the country's independence movement.  Ngugi wa Thiong'o's writing style is characterized by its use of Gikuyu language and its exploration of the complexities of East African culture. His works often blend elements of traditional oral storytelling with modern literary forms, reflecting his commitment to preserving and promoting African languages and cultures.  Ngugi wa Thiong'o's influence extends beyond his own writing, as he has been a vocal advocate for the use of African languages in literature and education. His work has inspired a generation of East African writers and continues to be widely read and studied today.  Reading recommendations for Ngugi wa Thiong'o's works include:  - "Decolonising the Mind" for its insightful analysis of the role of language in African literature and culture - "The River Between" for its poignant portrayal of the complexities of identity and culture in colonial Kenya - "Weep Not, Child" for its powerful exploration of the human cost of colonialism and the struggle for independence
Binyavanga Wainaina won awards for the following notable works:  One Day I Will Write About This Place  (memoir)  Jagua Nana  (novel)
